intro: Paepalanthus radicans, commonly known as the creeping buttercup, is a flowering plant native to South America. It is a member of the family Polygonaceae and is characterized by its low-growing, mat-forming habit. The plant features small, bright yellow flowers that bloom in clusters, typically during the warmer months. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in a waxy coating, which helps reduce water loss in its native arid environments. Paepalanthus radicans is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including grasslands and rocky areas.
